overview: From 2026-01-12 to 2026-01-13, elizaos/elizaos.github.io had 11 new PRs (0 merged), 0 new issues, and 3 active contributors.

topPRs.title: fix: render markdown in profile summary card
topPRs.author: standujar
topPRs.body:
Greptile Overview

### Greptile Summary This PR enhances the profile summary card by adding markdown rendering support using `react-markdown` and `remark-gfm`. The change replaces plain text rendering with proper markdown formatting, allowing headers, lists, links, and other markdown elements in AI-generated contributor summaries to display correctly. **What Changed:** - Added `react-markdown` and `remark-gfm` imports - Replaced `

` element with `

` wrapped `` component - Added Tailwind Typography prose classes for consistent markdown styling - Configured prose classes to match the card's design system (custom spacing, colors for headings, dark mode support) **Integration with Codebase:** The summary content is AI-generated markdown from the pipeline (see `src/lib/pipelines/summarize/aiContributorSummary.ts`), which produces structured markdown with headers, lists, and links. This change ensures that markdown renders correctly in the profile summary cards, matching the pattern already used in `SummaryContent.tsx` for full summary pages. **Security:** `react-markdown` is safe by default - it sanitizes HTML and only renders markdown elements unless explicitly configured with `rehype-raw` plugin (which is not used here). The summary data comes from the database, populated by server-side AI generation, so there's no user-controlled input risk. **Issue Found:** The existing truncation logic (line 53) slices at character 300, which can break markdown syntax by cutting through links, headers, or other elements. This needs to be addressed with markdown-aware truncation or an alternative approach. ### Confidence Score: 3/5 - This PR is safe to merge with caution - the markdown rendering is implemented correctly, but the truncation logic will cause rendering issues for long lifetime summaries - Score of 3 reflects that while the core markdown rendering implementation is correct and secure (proper use of react-markdown with GFM support, appropriate styling), there is a logic bug where the existing character-based truncation will break markdown syntax. This issue only affects lifetime summaries longer than 300 characters when not expanded. The bug won't cause crashes or security issues, but will result in malformed markdown rendering. The positive aspects are: libraries are already in dependencies, security is handled correctly by react-markdown's default sanitization, styling matches the design system, and the pattern is consistent with other markdown rendering in the codebase. - src/components/summary-card.tsx - specifically the truncation logic at lines 48-54 which needs to be made markdown-aware

Important Files Changed

File Analysis | Filename | Score | Overview | |----------|-------|----------| | src/components/summary-card.tsx | 3/5 | Adds markdown rendering to profile summaries but has a critical bug where character-based truncation can break markdown syntax mid-element |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant ProfilePage as Profile Page participant SummaryCard as Summary Card participant ReactMarkdown as React Markdown participant RemarkGFM as Remark GFM Plugin User->>ProfilePage: Visit /profile/[username] ProfilePage->>ProfilePage: Fetch user data from DB Note over ProfilePage: Includes lifetimeSummary,
monthlySummaries,
weeklySummaries ProfilePage->>SummaryCard: Render with summaries prop alt Lifetime summary & length > 300 SummaryCard->>SummaryCard: Truncate at char 300 Note over SummaryCard: ⚠️ May break markdown syntax end SummaryCard->>ReactMarkdown: Pass displayText ReactMarkdown->>RemarkGFM: Process markdown with GFM RemarkGFM->>ReactMarkdown: Return parsed AST ReactMarkdown->>ReactMarkdown: Render to React elements ReactMarkdown->>SummaryCard: Rendered markdown SummaryCard->>User: Display formatted content alt User clicks "Show more/less" User->>SummaryCard: Toggle isExpanded SummaryCard->>SummaryCard: Re-render with full/truncated text end ```

Bumps [zod](https://github.com/colinhacks/zod) from 3.25.76 to 4.3.5.
Release notes

Sourced from zod's releases.

v4.3.5

Commits:

v4.3.4

  • e01cd02b2f23d7e9078d3813830b146f8a2258b4 Support patternProperties for looserecord (#5592)
  • 089e5fbb0f58ce96d2c4fb34cd91724c78df4af5 Improve looseRecord docs
  • decef9c418d9a598c3f1bada06891ba5d922c5cd Fix lint
  • 9443aab00d44d5d5f4a7eada65fc0fc851781042 Drop iso time in fromJSONSchema
  • 66bda7491a1b9eab83bdeec0c12f4efc7290bd48 Remove .refine() from ZodMiniType
  • b4ab94ca608cd5b581bfc12b20dd8d95b35b3009 4.3.4

v4.3.3

Commits:

  • f3b2151959d215d405f54dff3c7ab3bf1fd887ca v4.3.3

v4.3.2

Commits:

  • bf96635d243118de6e4f260077aa137453790bf6 Loosen strictObjectinside intersection (#5587)
  • f71dc0182ab0f0f9a6be6295b07faca269e10179 Remove Juno (#5590)
  • 0f41e5a12a43e6913c9dcb501b2b5136ea86500d 4.3.2

v4.3.1

Commits:

  • 0fe88407a4149c907929b757dc6618d8afe998fc allow non-overwriting extends with refinements. 4.3.1

v4.3.0

This is Zod's biggest release since 4.0. It addresses several of Zod's longest-standing feature requests.

z.fromJSONSchema()

Convert JSON Schema to Zod (#5534, #5586)

You can now convert JSON Schema definitions directly into Zod schemas. This function supports JSON Schema "draft-2020-12", "draft-7", "draft-4", and OpenAPI 3.0.

import * as z from "zod";

const schema = z.fromJSONSchema({
type: "object",
properties: {
</tr></table>

... (truncated)

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=zod&package-manager=npm_and_yarn&previous-version=3.25.76&new-version=4.3.5)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

Greptile Overview

### Greptile Summary This PR upgrades Zod from version 3.24.1 to 4.3.5, which is a **major version bump** introducing breaking changes. ## Changes Overview - **Dependency**: `zod` upgraded from `^3.24.1` to `^4.3.5` - **Type**: Major version upgrade (potentially breaking) ## Critical Issue Found The codebase uses the `.toLowerCase()` method on a Zod string schema in `src/lib/walletLinking/readmeUtils.ts:8`, which has been **removed in Zod v4**. This will cause a runtime error when the schema is evaluated. ### Breaking Change Details In Zod v3, string schemas had convenience methods like `.toLowerCase()` and `.toUpperCase()`. These have been removed in v4 in favor of the more explicit `.transform()` method. **Current code (will break):** ```typescript chain: z.string().min(1).toLowerCase() ``` **Required fix:** ```typescript chain: z.string().min(1).transform(val => val.toLowerCase()) ``` ## Impact Assessment ### Files Affected - **Direct impact**: `src/lib/walletLinking/readmeUtils.ts` (1 location) - **Indirect impact**: Any code that uses `LinkedWalletSchema` for validation will fail ### Severity This is a **critical breaking change** that will cause runtime errors in the wallet linking functionality. The application will crash when attempting to validate wallet data. ## Other Compatibility Notes ✅ **Compatible patterns found:** - `z.object()`, `z.string()`, `z.number()`, `z.array()`, `z.enum()` - all compatible - `z.nativeEnum()` - still supported in v4 - `.optional()`, `.nullable()`, `.default()` - all compatible - `.datetime()` - compatible (no options passed) - `z.infer<>` - compatible ⚠️ **Redundant but working patterns:** - `.optional().default()` used in 3 locations - works but redundant (`.default()` alone makes field optional) ## Recommendation **DO NOT MERGE** until the breaking change in `src/lib/walletLinking/readmeUtils.ts` is fixed. After fixing, thorough testing of the wallet linking feature is required to ensure no runtime errors occur. ### Confidence Score: 1/5 - This PR contains a critical breaking change that will cause runtime errors in production - Score of 1/5 reflects a major version dependency upgrade with confirmed breaking changes. The codebase uses .toLowerCase() on a Zod schema which has been removed in v4, causing guaranteed runtime failures in wallet linking functionality. The fix is straightforward but mandatory before merge. - src/lib/walletLinking/readmeUtils.ts requires immediate attention - line 8 must be updated to use .transform() instead of .toLowerCase()

Important Files Changed

File Analysis | Filename | Score | Overview | |----------|-------|----------| | package.json | 2/5 | Zod upgrade from 3.24.1 to 4.3.5 introduces breaking changes; .toLowerCase() method used in codebase is removed in v4 |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Dev as Developer participant App as Application participant Zod as Zod Library participant Schema as readmeUtils.ts Note over Dev,Schema: Dependency Bump: Zod 3.24.1 → 4.3.5 Dev->>App: Install dependencies App->>Zod: Load Zod v4.3.5 Note over App,Schema: Runtime Execution App->>Schema: Import LinkedWalletSchema Schema->>Zod: z.string().min(1).toLowerCase() Zod-->>Schema: ❌ ERROR: .toLowerCase() method not found Note over Schema: Breaking Change in Zod v4 Note over Schema: .toLowerCase() removed
Must use .transform() instead Schema->>App: Runtime Error App->>Dev: Application crash Note over Dev,Schema: Required Fix Dev->>Schema: Update to .transform(val => val.toLowerCase()) Schema->>Zod: z.string().min(1).transform(...) Zod-->>Schema: ✓ Valid schema Schema->>App: Schema works correctly ```

Documentation

Other

v3.1.0

New Features

... (truncated)

Commits

Maintainer changes

This version was pushed to npm by [GitHub Actions](https://www.npmjs.com/~GitHub Actions), a new releaser for tailwind-merge since your current version.


[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=tailwind-merge&package-manager=npm_and_yarn&previous-version=2.6.0&new-version=3.4.0)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

Greptile Overview

### Greptile Summary This PR upgrades `tailwind-merge` from version 2.6.0 to 3.4.0, which brings performance improvements (>10% faster) and support for Tailwind CSS v4.1.5. ## Critical Issue Found **The `bun.lock` file was not updated** to reflect the new version. The lock file still references `tailwind-merge@2.6.0`, which creates a version mismatch that will cause all CI jobs to fail. ## Analysis ### Current Usage - `tailwind-merge` is imported once in `src/lib/utils.ts` via the `twMerge` function - Wrapped in a `cn()` utility function used throughout the codebase in **70+ component files** - Usage pattern: Standard class merging with `clsx` for conditional classes and `twMerge` for Tailwind class deduplication ### Version Jump (2.6.0 → 3.4.0) This is a **major version upgrade** from v2 to v3. According to the release notes: - v3.0.0 introduced breaking changes (not detailed in provided notes) - v3.1.0 - v3.4.0 added Tailwind CSS v4 support and performance optimizations - The usage pattern in this codebase (simple `twMerge(clsx(inputs))`) is standard and unlikely affected by breaking changes ### CI/CD Impact The PR will fail CI checks because: - `.github/workflows/pr-checks.yml` runs `bun install --frozen-lockfile` (lines 27, 49, 101, 163) - The `--frozen-lockfile` flag prevents installation if package.json and lock file don't match - All 4 CI jobs (check, build, test-pipelines, check-migrations) will fail ### Required Action Run `bun install` locally to update `bun.lock`, then commit both files together. ### Confidence Score: 0/5 - This PR cannot be merged as-is due to a critical lock file mismatch that will cause CI failures - Score of 0 reflects a blocking issue: the bun.lock file was not updated to match the package.json change. This will cause immediate CI failures when `bun install --frozen-lockfile` is executed in all workflow jobs. While the dependency upgrade itself appears safe (tailwind-merge is used in a standard pattern that's unlikely affected by breaking changes), the PR is not deployable without updating the lock file first. - package.json requires a corresponding bun.lock update - both files must be committed together

Important Files Changed

File Analysis | Filename | Score | Overview | |----------|-------|----------| | package.json | 0/5 | Updated tailwind-merge from 2.6.0 to 3.4.0, but bun.lock file was not updated, causing version mismatch |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Dev as Developer participant PKG as package.json participant LOCK as bun.lock participant CI as CI/CD Pipeline participant Runtime as Application Runtime Dev->>PKG: Update tailwind-merge: 2.6.0 → 3.4.0 Note over LOCK: ❌ NOT UPDATED
(still references 2.6.0) Dev->>CI: Push PR #211 CI->>LOCK: Run `bun install --frozen-lockfile` LOCK-->>CI: ❌ FAIL: Lock file mismatch Note over CI: All CI jobs fail:
- check
- build
- test-pipelines
- check-migrations Note over Dev,Runtime: If lock file were updated: Dev->>LOCK: Run `bun install` LOCK->>LOCK: Update to 3.4.0 Dev->>CI: Push both files CI->>LOCK: Run `bun install --frozen-lockfile` LOCK-->>CI: ✓ Success CI->>Runtime: Deploy with tailwind-merge@3.4.0 Runtime->>Runtime: cn() utility uses twMerge v3.4.0 Note over Runtime: Used in 70+ component files ```

topPRs.author: dependabot
topPRs.body:

You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

Greptile Overview

### Greptile Summary This PR updates `@types/node` from 22.10.5 to 25.0.6, a major version jump spanning 3 major versions. While this is a standard Dependabot update, it introduces a significant concern: **Primary Issue: Runtime/Types Version Mismatch** The `@types/node` package v25 provides TypeScript type definitions for Node.js 25.x APIs and features. However, this project: - Uses Next.js 15.4.10, which officially supports Node.js 18.18+ or 20.x (not 25.x) - Runs CI/CD on ubuntu-latest with Bun, which typically uses Node.js 18 or 20 - Has no explicit Node.js version constraint in package.json This mismatch means the TypeScript compiler will assume Node.js 25 APIs are available, potentially allowing code that references newer APIs to pass type checking but fail at runtime. **Impact Assessment** Current usage of Node.js types in the codebase: - `NodeJS.ErrnoException` type in error handling (src/lib/fsHelpers.ts) - `process.env` for environment variables (throughout) - Node.js core modules: crypto, fs, path (drizzle/migrate.ts) These common APIs are stable across versions, so immediate breakage is unlikely. However, future development might inadvertently use Node.js 25-specific features that won't work in the actual runtime. **Recommendation** Align `@types/node` version with your actual Node.js runtime version to ensure type safety matches runtime capabilities. If running Node.js 20.x, downgrade to `@types/node@^20.x.x`. If running Node.js 18.x, use `@types/node@^18.x.x`. ### Confidence Score: 3/5 - This PR introduces a runtime/types version mismatch that could cause subtle issues - Score of 3 reflects moderate risk: the version jump skips 3 major versions and creates a mismatch between type definitions (Node.js 25) and likely runtime (Node.js 18/20). While existing code uses stable APIs that won't break immediately, this mismatch could allow future code to pass type checking but fail at runtime. The PR will likely work but goes against TypeScript best practices of matching types to runtime. - package.json requires attention to align @types/node version with actual Node.js runtime version

Important Files Changed

File Analysis | Filename | Score | Overview | |----------|-------|----------| | package.json | 3/5 | Major version bump of @types/node from 22.10.5 to 25.0.6 (3 major versions) - potential runtime/types mismatch concern |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Dev as Developer participant Dep as Dependabot participant CI as CI/CD (Node 18/20) participant TS as TypeScript Compiler participant RT as Runtime (Bun/Node) Dep->>Dep: Detect @types/node update available Dep->>Dev: Create PR: v22.10.5 → v25.0.6 Note over Dep,Dev: 3 major version jump Dev->>CI: Merge PR CI->>CI: Install dependencies (bun install) CI->>TS: Run typecheck Note over TS: Uses @types/node v25 definitions
(Node.js 25.x types) TS->>TS: Type check passes Note over TS: Assumes Node.js 25 APIs available CI->>CI: Run build (Next.js) CI->>RT: Execute on Node.js 18/20 Note over RT: Runtime has older APIs
than types suggest alt If using Node 25 specific APIs RT-->>CI: Potential runtime error Note over RT: API not available in Node 18/20 else Using stable APIs (current case) RT->>CI: Success Note over RT: Common APIs work across versions end ```

topPRs.title: chore(deps): bump react-markdown from 9.1.0 to 10.1.0
topPRs.author: dependabot
topPRs.body:
Bumps [react-markdown](https://github.com/remarkjs/react-markdown) from 9.1.0 to 10.1.0.
Release notes

Sourced from react-markdown's releases.

10.1.0

Add

  • 939c667 Add fallback prop to MarkdownHooks by @​remcohaszing in remarkjs/react-markdown#897

Fix

  • a40ae2e Fix race condition in MarkdownHooks by @​remcohaszing in remarkjs/react-markdown#896

Full Changelog: https://github.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/compare/10.0.1...10.1.0

10.0.1

  • 7c17ede Fix TypeScript performance around components by @​remcohaszing in remarkjs/react-markdown#893

Full Changelog: https://github.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/compare/10.0.0...10.0.1

10.0.0

  • aaaa40b Remove support for className prop see “Remove className”

Full Changelog: https://github.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/compare/9.1.0...10.0.0

Changelog

Sourced from react-markdown's changelog.

Changelog

All notable changes will be documented in this file.

10.0.0 - 2025-02-20

  • aaaa40b Remove support for className prop migrate: see “Remove className” below

Remove className

The className prop was removed. If you want to add classes to some element that wraps the markdown you can explicitly write that element and add the class to it. You can then choose yourself which tag name to use and whether to add other props.

Before:

<Markdown className="markdown-body">{markdown}</Markdown>

After:

<div className="markdown-body">
  <Markdown>{markdown}</Markdown>
</div>
Commits
  • 44d2e4a 10.1.0
  • f2369cd Refactor docs
  • 26fdfe0 Update docs
  • 544bff6 Refactor code-style
  • 939c667 Add fallback prop to MarkdownHooks
  • a40ae2e Fix race condition in MarkdownHooks
  • ad7f37f Add lifecycle tests for MarkdownHooks
  • 2792c32 10.0.1
  • 7c17ede Fix performance around components

Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

Greptile Overview

### Greptile Summary This PR upgrades `react-markdown` from version 9.1.0 to 10.1.0, which includes several improvements and one breaking change. ## Key Changes in react-markdown 10.x **Version 10.1.0** (target version): - Adds `fallback` prop to `MarkdownHooks` - Fixes race condition in `MarkdownHooks` **Version 10.0.1**: - Fixes TypeScript performance around components **Version 10.0.0** (breaking change): - **Removed support for `className` prop** - This is a breaking change that requires wrapping the component in a div if you need to apply classes ## Compatibility Analysis ✅ **Good news**: The codebase already follows the recommended pattern: - The only usage of `ReactMarkdown` is in `src/app/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/components/SummaryContent.tsx` - It correctly wraps the component in a `
` with the className, rather than passing className directly to `` - This means the breaking change will NOT affect this codebase ✅ **Dependencies are compatible**: - React 19.0.0 is supported (react-markdown 9.1.0 requires >=18) - remark-gfm@4.0.0 is compatible - unist-util-visit@5.0.0 is compatible - Custom remark plugin (`remarkRemoveFirstH1`) uses standard APIs that remain unchanged ## Critical Issue ❌ **The `bun.lock` file was not updated**: This is a critical issue that will prevent the upgrade from taking effect. When `package.json` is modified without updating the lockfile: - The actual installed version remains at 9.1.0 - CI/CD builds using `--frozen-lockfile` will fail - This creates version inconsistencies across environments ## Recommendation The upgrade itself is safe and compatible with the codebase, but the PR is incomplete without the lockfile update. The maintainers should run `bun install` to update `bun.lock` before merging. ### Confidence Score: 2/5 - This PR cannot be safely merged without updating the lockfile - it will cause CI/CD failures - The dependency upgrade itself is compatible with the codebase (no breaking changes affect the current usage), but the missing lockfile update is a critical blocker. The PR will fail CI checks that use `--frozen-lockfile` flag, and even if merged, the dependency won't actually be upgraded in production builds. Score reflects that the intent is good but the implementation is incomplete. - package.json requires a corresponding bun.lock update to complete the dependency upgrade

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Dev as Developer/Dependabot participant PR as Pull Request participant CI as CI/CD (pr-checks.yml) participant Bun as Bun Package Manager participant App as Next.js App participant RC as ReactMarkdown Component Note over Dev,PR: Dependency Update Flow Dev->>PR: Update package.json (react-markdown: ^10.1.0) Note over PR: ⚠️ Missing: bun.lock update PR->>CI: Trigger PR checks CI->>Bun: bun install --frozen-lockfile Note over Bun: ❌ Fails: package.json & bun.lock mismatch Bun--xCI: Error: lockfile out of sync Note over Dev,Bun: Correct Flow (with lockfile) Dev->>Dev: Run: bun install Dev->>PR: Commit package.json + bun.lock PR->>CI: Trigger PR checks CI->>Bun: bun install --frozen-lockfile Bun->>Bun: Verify lockfile matches package.json Bun->>Bun: Install react-markdown@10.1.0 CI->>CI: Run build CI->>App: Build Next.js application App->>RC: Import ReactMarkdown from react-markdown Note over RC: Version 10.1.0 installed RC->>App: Component renders markdown in SummaryContent Note over App: ✅ Build succeeds ```
